Why are passwords shorter than 8 characters easy to crack? (According to Snowden) [0] When you add a character to a password, the number of possible permutations goes up exponentially. [1] Lets assume we have a simple password requirement - only upper case letters. [2] Below are the number of possible passwords based on character count [3] - 1 character - 26^1 - 26 combinations
- 2 characters - 26^2 - 676 combinations
- 3 characters - 26^3 - 17,576 combinations
- 4 characters - 26^4 - 456,976 combinations
- 5 characters - 26^5 - 11,881,376 combinations
- 6 characters - 26^6 - 308,915,776 combinations
- 7 characters - 26^7 - 8,031,810,176 combinations
- 8 characters - 26^8 - 208,827,064,576 combinations [4] So, even in our simple system, an 8 character password has over 200 billion possible combinations. [5] ~~This is getting beyond a computer's ability to brute force (just keep trying combinations until it gets it right) ability.~~ [6] While this is still within the average computer's ability to crack, you can see how even in our simple system, more characters becomes more difficult [7] *Edit:  Look, I am not suggesting that an eight-character, upper case letters only password is a good idea or even used by most systems. [8] I was just creating an easy to understand, ELI5 example of entropy.

Why does salt water help your gums heal after a deep periodontal cleaning? [0] Osmosis. [1] During a deep periodontal cleaning, the water jet blasts lots of bacteria and other debris off your teeth and into your gums, creating lots of micro-abrasions in the process. [2] Salt water creates negative osmotic pressure, which draws water from your blood and lymph fluids through those micro-abrasions and cleans all the junk out of them. [3] Clean wounds heal faster.

Why do semi trucks leave behind huge chunks of tires on the road? [0] Can confirm what others have said: [1] They use retreaded tires on tractors in any position except steer (the very front two tires). [2] Retreading is a system by which a used tire has new tread applied to it at a tire plant, thereby making it a "refurbished" tire. [3] Retread tires are used on every position on a truck except the steer axle, only new tires go on steer axle (this is the very front two tires on a truck, if they are not new then they are against DOT regulation). [4] Is it safe? [5] By and large, yes, we have never had a major failure across the board in a retread campaign. [6] Do I recommend driving next to a truck or a trailer on the highway? [7] Absolutely not. [8] It isn't even so much because of the tires but because of the driver, sitting on the side of one they usually won't see you, if there is a blowout the tread may hit your car and damage it severely (we have large steel belts, sort of like in your car, but unfurled they would be about the size of your car). [9] Another thing is that if a retread blows then it could blow out other tires, the truck could swerve and destroy your car. [10] If you are on city streets being next to a truck is a lot like being next to a car so I wouldn't worry there but on highways I would suggest sticking as far as you can away from a tractor, especially one that has a trailer attached because trailer tire retreads tend to be several times retreaded tractor tires. [11] tl;dr tractors have copies of copies of copies of tires and therefore trend toward the weaker side. [12] Source: I am a parts manager (that deals with tires every day) for a national trucking company.

what were the reasons for the revolt of 1857 [0]  The sepoys , a generic term used for native Indian soldiers of the Bengal Army derived from the Persian word sepāhī ( سپاهی ) meaning `` infantry soldier '' , had their own list of grievances against the British East Indian Company ( BEIC ) administration , caused mainly by the ethnic gulf between the European officers and their Indian troops . [1] The spark that led to a mutiny in several sepoy companies was the issue of new gunpowder cartridges for the Enfield rifle in February , 1857 . [2] A rumour was spread that the cartridges were made from cow and pig fat . [3] Loading the Enfield required tearing open the greased cartridge with one 's teeth . [4] This would have insulted both Hindu and Muslim religious practices ; cows were considered holy by Hindus while pigs were considered unclean by Muslims . [5] Underlying grievances over British taxation and recent land annexations by the BEIC were ignited by the sepoy mutineers and within weeks dozens of units of the Indian army joined peasant armies in widespread rebellion . [6] The old aristocracy , both Muslim and Hindu , who were seeing their power steadily eroded by the East India Company , also rebelled against British rule . [7] Another important discontent among the Indian rulers was that the british policies of conquest had created unrest among many indian rulers . [8] The policies like the doctrine of lapse , Subsidiary Alliance deprived Indian rulers of their power and status .

input_txt: Why do dogs live a shorter life than humans? [0] Let's say that a species is being successful if it can continually create viable offspring and replace it's individual organisms at least as fast as they are dying. [1] There's multiple paths to this in terms of reproductive strategies. [2] One strategy, is to maximize the number of offspring, even if that reduces the chances of any particular individual surviving. [3] An alternate strategy is a lower number of offspring, but taking more care to ensure their survival. [4] Dogs are somewhere in the middle, while humans are basically at the far end of the "fewer offspring" side. [5] And following those different paths through evolution has resulted in significant biological differences. [6] The human brain is significantly more capable than a dog's, but it also needs much more time to fully develop to the point where you get a human being capable of self preservation and successful reproduction. [7] A wolf (which dogs were bred from) is physically and mentally fit enough to reproduce and care for its offspring within a couple of years of its birth, can create a few litters of puppies, and then get old and die within a decade. [8] Over that same 10 years, a human baby will still not even be developed enough to live on its own, much less create and care for a baby. [9] If you assume about 15 years for a human to develop enough to be in a position to successfully create and care for a child, and then another 15 years for them to care for their child to the point where that child can be independent, then that's 30 years. [10] And that's just for one kid. [11] Before modern medicine came around, children died much more often, so the average mother might give birth to 5+ kids, so you're looking at being 35+ when your last child doesn't need you any longer. [12] And 35 was a pretty typical life expectancy for much of the history of humanity.

input_txt: If wage gap exists between the sexes, why can't businesses hire more women as a way of saving money on salaries? [0] They could seek out women, but it is illegal to pay someone more or less based solely on their sex, age, etc. [1] That said, the wage gap doesn't really exist in the way that it is often portrayed. [2] Generally speaking there is little to no wage gap for the same work in the same field/position. [3] The wage gap is simply taking all income of full time earners of men vs women in the country and comparing them. [4] This "gap" of all overall earned income between the sexes doesn't take into account actual hours worked, education level, position, fields they elect to go into, etc. [5] Women as a whole tend to work less hours, in jobs that are less stressful/dangerous, have more flexibility with hours and choose to go into fields that are generally less paying than men. [6] This among many other similar factors is what contributes to the vast majority of the wage gap. [7] There's a lot of propaganda and misleading information in the news/media that try to make people believe otherwise, but it goes against all facts and data. [8] It's more of a politically correct argument than a sound/rational one. [9] The truth is that women are more likely to get a degree and in nearly all metropolitan areas of the US single, childless women earn more than men. [10] As these trends continue in favor of women, young men have begun to speak out and advancing the myth of the wage gap is slowly becoming less politically correct as the current generation of workers enter the job market and find that men are actually less "privileged" than women in many regards. [11] The "wage gap" is largely a product of life choices that women and families make for themselves and not something that can be explained squarely as a product of bias in the workplace.

input_txt: what is the purpose of having multiple codons [0] There are 64 different codons ( 61 codons encoding for amino acids plus 3 stop codons ) but only 20 different translated amino acids . [1] The overabundance in the number of codons allows many amino acids to be encoded by more than one codon . [2] Because of such redundancy it is said that the genetic code is degenerate . [3] The genetic codes of different organisms are often biased towards using one of the several codons that encode the same amino acid over the others -- that is , a greater frequency of one will be found than expected by chance .  [4] How such biases arise is a much debated area of molecular evolution . [5] Codon usage tables detailing genomic codon usage bias for most organisms in GenBank and RefSeq can be found in the HIVE - Codon Usage Table database .

input_txt: Why does injecting air bubbles into your veins kill you? [0] _URL_0_ [1] > [2] Small bubbles can block capillaries in vital organs, most urgently the brain, causing anything from pain and inflammation to neurological damage and paralysis. [3] A small bubble impedes blood flow the same way a solid obstruction would — the bubble's surface tension relative to its size is too great for the force of blood to break it up or shove it along. [4] Bad? Yes. Fatal? [5] Probably not, although see below. [6] > [7] A big bubble, on the other hand, gets us into the vapor lock scenario. [8] Your heart, like the fuel pump in an old car (cars with modern fuel injection work differently), is a simple mechanical device. [9] In ordinary operation, its contracting chambers squeeze the blood out and force it through the circulatory system. [10] All is well. [11] Now imagine a massive air embolus shows up and your heart starts squeezing on that. [12] There's nothing to get any purchase on; the air just compresses. [13] Blood flow stops, and eventually so does your heart.

input_txt: how does the nuclear charge of elements in the same period affect their size [0] In single - electron atoms , the average separation of an electron from the nucleus is determined by the subshell it belongs to , and decreases with increasing charge on the nucleus ; this in turn leads to a decrease in atomic radius . [1] In multi-electron atoms , the decrease in radius brought about by an increase in nuclear charge is partially offset by increasing electrostatic repulsion among electrons . [2] In particular , a `` shielding effect '' operates : i.e. , as electrons are added in outer shells , electrons already present shield the outer electrons from nuclear charge , making them experience a lower effective charge on the nucleus . [3] The shielding effect exerted by the inner electrons decreases in the order s > p > d > f . Usually , as a particular subshell is filled in a period , atomic radius decreases . [4] This effect is particularly pronounced in the case of lanthanides , as the 4f subshell which is filled across these elements is not very effective at shielding the outer shell ( n = 5 and n = 6 ) electrons . [5] Thus the shielding effect is less able to counter the decrease in radius caused by increasing nuclear charge . [6] This leads to `` lanthanide contraction '' . [7] The ionic radius drops from 103 pm for lanthanum ( III ) to 86.1 pm for lutetium ( III ) .

input_txt: What does it mean when music is written in a certain key? [0] Think of the key as a starting point for a typical scale used in a piece of music. [1] Each song will have the same basic scale in order for it to sound pleasing to the ear or, in the right key. [2] Your basic key for music is the key of C, which employs the notes C through G and back to B again, naturally with no "sharps" or "flats." [3] These scales can be offset starting with a different note other than C. After this is done, the pattern of sound differences must be carried over to the new notes by using sharps and flats. [4] Using the C major and G major keys as an example, the C scale would read C,D,E,F,G,A,B, with a smaller pitch gap between E-F and B-C, called a half-step. [5] These small gaps will change based on whether the key is major or minor. [6] With a G major scale, you start on G and implement the half-steps into the same places they would be in the C scale. [7] With Gmaj we see G,A,B,C,D,E,F#(sharp), keeping the half-steps where they should be (B-C, F#-G)

Why do websites make you have a complicated password when most account breaches come from a hack and not just guessing? [0] When people hack sites for passwords, they usually get a list of the hashed passwords.  [1] That means when you put in your password, the site can check if it's the same password you signed up with but it doesn't know what the password is.  [2] It's like a one-way secret message.
 [3] The way hackers figure out passwords is they know common hashing techniques and they guess common passwords using those techniques. [4] Since "password123" is a common password, they'll put that in the hash, see what comes out, and match that output to the stolen list of hashed passwords they got.  [5] If they can't guess your password to input, then they won't be able to know what it is.
 [6] Complex passwords make it harder to guess the hashed passwords once they're stolen. [7] The biggest factors for making a password hard to guess are the total numbers of characters you can use and the length. [8] So forcing you to have three special characters and two capitals and a number doesn't really help, but allowing you to use any character and requiring your password to be long does help.  [9] In other words, "a%6L7" looks like a more securepassword than"!X [10] XthisismypasswordforthissiteX!", but the latter is actually more secure since it's longer and can possibly use just as many symbols.  [11] Longer passwords are harder to guess because the possible combinations of guesses increase quickly as you add additional characters.
